etymologies: mid 16th century. From mark + land. Compare post-classical Latin marcata terrae a mark's worth of land, and the Anglo-Norman equivalent marché de terre. Old English mearcland and Old Icelandic markland borderland, wasteland are unrelated

definitions: A piece of land having an annual rental value of one mark. Hence also: a unit of land based on this value, used in land assessment.
An area of land having the capital value of one mark. Usually used as a unit of land assessment and subdivided into eight ures.
